Concept_BELIEVES_IN.manifestation: The narrator reflects on how grown-ups fail to understand the world as children do.
The narrator expresses how he gave up his dream of being a painter because grown-ups did not understand his drawings.
The little prince asks the narrator to draw a sheep, showing his belief in the power of imagination.
The narrator draws the sheep, showing his willingness to engage with the little prince's imaginative world.
The little prince's questions about the narrator's plane and his origin reveal his curiosity about the nature of reality.
The little prince's questions about the sheep and the box reveal his search for meaning in the world.
The narrator reflects on how grown-ups are only interested in figures and numbers, not in the essential things in life.
The little prince is concerned about the baobabs and their potential to destroy his planet, showing his belief in the importance of taking care of one's environment.
The little prince explains the importance of pulling up baobabs, showing his belief in the importance of responsibility.
The little prince loves sunsets and finds comfort in them, showing his belief in the importance of finding beauty and meaning in life.
The little prince is upset that the flower's thorns are of no use, showing his belief in the importance of love and the value of things.
The little prince is upset about the flower and the sheep, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The narrator is ashamed of his own behavior and realizes the importance of the little prince's feelings.
The little prince cares for his rose, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince is hurt by the rose's vanity, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince prepares to leave his planet, showing his belief in the importance of responsibility and the need to move on.
The king believes in his own authority and the importance of being obeyed.
The conceited man believes in the importance of being admired.
The tippler drinks to forget, showing his belief in the power of escapism.
The businessman believes in the importance of owning things and being accurate.
The lamplighter believes in the importance of following orders.
The geographer believes in the importance of recording eternal things.
The little prince befriends the fox, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The fox explains the meaning of 'tame', showing his belief in the importance of establishing ties.
The fox explains the importance of the time spent with the little prince, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince understands that his rose is unique because of the time he spent with her, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince learns the fox's secret: what is essential is invisible to the eye, showing his belief in the importance of the heart.
The little prince understands that he is responsible for his rose, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince reflects on the meaning of life and the importance of finding what one is looking for.
The little prince reflects on the meaning of life and the importance of finding what one is looking for.
The narrator reflects on the meaning of life and the importance of finding what one is looking for.
The little prince explains that one must look with the heart, showing his belief in the importance of the heart.
The little prince accepts his fate, showing his belief in the importance of responsibility and love.
The little prince explains that what is essential is invisible to the eye, showing his belief in the importance of the heart.
The little prince explains that he will be in the stars, showing his belief in the importance of love and the connection between people.

The narrator reflects on the little prince and the importance of the heart.
